plant.description:
Brief Description
• Appearance: Mistletoe is an evergreen shrub featuring a round, highly branched green stem with ovoid, opposite-facing leaves1. The plant produces distinct white berries that each contain a single seed1.
• Habitat and Common Locations: In its natural habitat, mistletoe grows as a perennial parasitic plant that attaches itself to deciduous trees1. It is most commonly found inside homes during the winter months, as it is a very popular festive decoration brought indoors for the Christmas holiday season

toxins.name: Lectins and viscotoxins (which are toxic proteins)
toxins.description: in cats: These toxic proteins act as severe gastrointestinal irritants and cardiovascular depressants1.... When ingested, they can cause profuse vomiting and diarrhea, dilated pupils, and rapid, labored breathing2. Systemically, they affect the heart, causing a slowed heart rate and low blood pressure, which can ultimately lead to shock and death from cardiovascular collapse
toxins.concentration_notes: These toxins are found in all parts of the plant, though the leaves are considered to be more toxic than the berries14. While severe mistletoe toxicity is uncommon and usually requires a cat to eat a large amount of the plant, small ingestions are still potent enough to cause mild to severe stomach upset

toxins.name: Phoratoxins
toxins.description: in cats: Working alongside the lectins, phoratoxins specifically target the heart muscle and cardiovascular system13. They are responsible for inducing dangerous drops in blood pressure (hypotension) and abnormally slow heart rates (bradycardia), which can lead to profound weakness and odd behavior
toxins.concentration_notes: Phoratoxins are distributed throughout the plant1. Fortunately, a cat must typically consume a large amount of the plant for these chemicals to reach a severely toxic, life-threatening threshold

toxins.name: Amines
toxins.description: in cats: Amines are present alongside the toxic proteins and contribute to the rapid onset of both gastrointestinal distress and cardiovascular shock2. They play a role in symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhea, dilated pupils, and labored breathing
toxins.concentration_notes: Amines are found in all parts of the mistletoe plant2. Like the other compounds, a large toxic dose is generally required to trigger fatal cardiovascular collapse

symptoms.name: Gastrointestinal upset, including vomiting and diarrhea (which can be profuse)
symptoms.notes:
If a cat only eats a small amount (like a few leaves or berries), the symptoms are typically limited to mild gastrointestinal irritation14. However, ingesting larger amounts leads to severe gastrointestinal distress56. Additionally, many store-bought mistletoe decorations use plastic berries; if a cat ingests a large amount of these fake berries, it can cause a physical gastrointestinal obstruction4.
2. Cardiovascular Depression (Slowed Heart Rate and Low Blood Pressure)

symptoms.name: Slowed heart rate (bradycardia), low blood pressure (hypotension), and potential cardiovascular collapse
symptoms.onset: Within hours of ingesting a toxic dose
symptoms.notes:
These life-threatening cardiovascular effects are caused by the plant's lectins and phoratoxins3. Fortunately, severe heart toxicity is relatively uncommon and usually only occurs if the cat consumes a large amount of the plant34. If left untreated after a large ingestion, it can lead to shock and death from cardiovascular collapse2.
3. Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Difficulty breathing or rapid, labored breathing
symptoms.onset: Within hours of ingesting a toxic dose
symptoms.notes:
This symptom is typically seen in severe cases of toxicity alongside cardiovascular collapse and shock23.
4. Weakness, Odd Behavior, and Dilated Pupils

symptoms.name: Weakness, odd behavior, and dilated pupils
symptoms.notes: The profound weakness and lethargy a cat experiences are usually secondary effects caused by the significant drop in blood pressure and the slowed heart rate

treatments.name: Medically Induced Emesis and Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: If the mistletoe was ingested recently, the veterinarian will administer medication to induce vomiting and clear the highly toxic leaves or berries from the stomach. After vomiting, they will administer activated charcoal to bind to any remaining toxins in the digestive tract and prevent them from being absorbed into the bloodstream.
treatments.notes:
This is the most urgent step to prevent the toxins from triggering severe cardiovascular and neurological symptoms. You should never attempt to induce vomiting at home without direct veterinary supervision.
2. Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy

treatments.name: IV Fluid Therapy and Blood Pressure Support
treatments.description: The cat is placed on IV fluids to maintain hydration, support kidney function, and help flush the absorbed toxins out of the body.
treatments.notes:
Because mistletoe poisoning can cause profuse vomiting and diarrhea—as well as a dangerous drop in blood pressure (hypotension)—aggressive fluid therapy is critical to prevent severe dehydration and cardiovascular collapse.
3. Cardiovascular Monitoring and Pharmacological Support

treatments.name: ECG Monitoring and Heart Medications (e.g., Atropine)
treatments.description: The veterinary team will continuously monitor the cat's heart rhythm and blood pressure using an electrocardiogram (ECG). If the cat's heart rate drops dangerously low (bradycardia), the vet will administer specific cardiovascular drugs, such as atropine, to stabilize the heart rate.
treatments.notes:
This targeted treatment is necessary because the phoratoxins in mistletoe directly depress the cardiovascular system. Cats that have ingested a large amount of the plant are at the highest risk for requiring emergency heart stabilization.
4. Symptomatic and Supportive Care

treatments.name: Anti-emetics and Oxygen Therapy
treatments.description: The veterinarian will administer anti-emetic medications to stop severe nausea and vomiting. If the cat is experiencing respiratory distress, supplemental oxygen will be provided.
treatments.notes: Even after the plant is removed from the stomach, the severe irritation to the mucosal lining of the gastrointestinal tract requires medical management to keep the cat comfortable and prevent further fluid loss.
